Articles.Content:
In an attempt to set a Kerbal record for speed on ground, Donald Kermbell set a speed of 100m/s. Kerbiss Kerb Records is now opening the record to all out there. The attempts must be have screenshots of the building stage, any tests and the final speed. Kerbiss Kerb Records Are setting rules that must be followed.

Rules:

1. The vehicle must be wheeled.

2. The record attempt must stay on the ground during the attempt.

3. The record attempt must be manned.

4. The vehicle must stay intact.

5. The vehicle must stay on the runway.

6. When the attempt is over, and the vehicle has left the opposite end of the runway, the vehicle must stop safely.

7. The vehicle must be only stock parts.

All attempts will be verified on the website

Record Attempts should be entered on the website: http://kerbisslerbrecords.weebly.com/

Good Luck.

On a seperate note; Kerbiss Kerb Records are allowing applications for new records to be entered also.

Edited December 17, 2013 by Kerbiss Kerb Records

First off, welcome to the forums!

Secondly, as I've noted in my own edit to your post, we discourage people from posting personal contact details in public places on the forums, as it can lead to unwanted attention. Furthermore, there's no reason people can't simply post their screenshots in a response to your post. For one, it will ensure that people know that you intend to be a fair judge who keeps everything above the board (not that we'd have any reason to suspect you, of course, but that extra effort helps...)

I'd finally recommend that you take a look at our official Challenge Submission Guide and ensure that your challenge is within those guidelines. In particular, have you attempted the challenge yourself to see if it's actually feasible?

Have a nice day

In answer to your Queries. The Email Entries are to stop the forum being clogged up. All evidence, with the record, will be posted on the Kerbiss Kerb Records Website. The Chalenge is feasible. With the speed from Donald Kermbell set by myself. There will be an official Record entry form on the site, when the site is finished.

There's already bunch of land speed record challenges around. The only point in which this one is different from those I have seen is that the vehicle can leave the runway but has to survive braking. So far it was either stopping while still on the runway, or don't care what happens next. Not a substantial difference IMO. One way or another I am expecting clumps of sepatrons to be the favorite.

Don't take it as if I am trying to stop you but I think making a website for such challenge is unnecessary. It's much more comfortable to see results in the first post, just as it's done in all other challenges.
The website is for, not only this single challenge, but a host of them. As I think up challenges I will add them to both the site and the forum.
